basics.name: Linh Pham
basics.summary: Undergraduate researcher in adaptive AI, VR, and HCI at Duke Kunshan & Duke University. My work focuses on trust, explainability, and user understanding in immersive AI systems.

education.area: Dual B.S. in Computer Science and Interdisciplinary Studies (Computation & Design; Computer Science)
highlights: Bachelor thesis: Trust and Reliability in Sketch-Based AI Systems for VR.
Selected coursework: Probability & Statistics, Algorithms, Modeling & Predicting, Computer Organization, Discrete Math.

research.position: Undergraduate Researcher – Trust & Reliability in Sketch-Based AI Systems for VR
highlights: Built a VR sketching environment tracking controller trajectories, pauses, and stroke smoothness.
Integrated base64-encoded sketches and behavioral features with the Gemini API to generate personality feedback.
Designed a user study with trust scales and feedback-stability manipulations to examine how users calibrate trust.

research.position: Summer Research Scholar – VR Bodystorming Tool for Collaborative Design
highlights: Co-developed a multi-user VR prototyping tool for spatial ideation, choreography, and lighting design.
Designed UI layouts, icons, and modular 3D props (walls, dividers, lighting rigs, rotational menus).
Improved interaction responsiveness by optimizing input handling and object-update logic.

research.position: Research Assistant – iRow Adaptive VR Exergame
highlights: Helped build an adaptive VR rowing exergame integrating biometric sensing and generative environments.
Supported a pilot usability study assessing engagement, comfort, and perceived safety.
Analyzed how participants interpreted the same adaptive behavior differently in terms of support vs. control.

research.company: Fudan University – GRIPS Program (Big Data and Networking Lab)
highlights: Fine-tuned Qwen2.5-1.5B-Instruct using LoRA on a financial QA dataset via HuggingFace SFTTrainer.
Improved answer accuracy by ~25% and reduced hallucinations by ~30% using prompt-based evaluation.
Reviewed Transformer architectures (BERT, GPT), attention mechanisms, and pretraining vs. fine-tuning strategies.

research.position: Research Assistant – VR Catheter Placement Trainer
highlights: Developed a Unity-based VR simulation for catheter placement training with haptic interactions.
Built instructor-facing tools for authoring procedural scenarios without modifying code.
Optimized 3D environment layout, lighting, and object hierarchy for more stable frame times in VR.
Supports 50+ residents with wellness, conflict mediation, and emergency response.
Directed practices; choreographed and performed for >1000 attendees.
2nd Place – Pom-Pom (Youth Open B), 2025 China Yangtze River Delta Cheer Dance Competition.
Managed events and budget for ~400 DKU students studying at Duke.
Led community building and wellness programming.
